docs.lead_paragraph: BERNARDS TOWNSHIP ARESIDENTIAL treatment center for children that has been under investigation for two and a half years has been ordered by the state to come up with plans by Dec. 31 to correct ''weaknesses in administration.'' The center, Bonnie Brae, is one of 26 privately operated residential programs in New Jersey that contract with the state's Division of Youth and Family Services to treat and board troubled children. Among the incidents reported since the Somerset County Prosecutor began a grand jury investigation have been abuse of children, attacks on teachers and other staff workers, vandalism and financial irregularities. In addition, it has been alleged that unlicensed teachers have been hired. Gil Farr, the assistant prosecutor in charge of the investigation, said he had received reports ''of staff attacking students, students attacking staff and other alleged improprieties.''

headline.main: STATE DEMANDS YOUTH RESIDENCE UNDER INQUIRY MAKE CHANGES

docs.lead_paragraph: ONE OF every five babies born in New Jersey in 1980 was delivered by Caesarean section, according to the state's Department of Health. Thirteen years ago, only one baby in 20 born in the state was delivered surgically. This steep rise in New Jersey's Caesarean birth rate, which parallels the nationwide upward curve, has led many to ask whether the procedure is performed too frequently today. There are no simple answers, experts on both sides of the issue say. The trend toward Caesarean deliveries represents a fundamental change in the practice of obstetrics and coincides with parents' mounting demands for more control over how their children are born.

headline.main: RISE IN CAESAREAN BIRTHS STIRS DISPUTE

docs.lead_paragraph: An expert committee assessing the safety of nitrites and nitrates as food additives reported today that eliminating them from cured meats would probably not have a major impact on human health. The committee concluded that cured meats accounted for only a small proportion of human exposure to cancer-causing nitrosamines, which can be formed by nitrites and nitrates. A far larger amount of nitrosamines may reach the average consumer through cigarette smoke, baked goods, vegetables, cosmetics, automobile interiors and drinking water, according to the committee chairman, Dr. Maclyn McCarty, a bacteriologist at The Rockefeller University in New York City. Nonetheless, the committee, convened by the National Academy of Sciences at the request of the Food and Drug Administration and the United States Department of Agriculture, urged at a news conference that the use of nitrites and nitrates in meat products be reduced ''to the extent that protection against botulism is not compromised.''

headline.main: A REPORT ON NITRITES FINDS CURED MEATS ARE RELATIVELY SAFE
